name: portal

portal noun [C]
(WAY TO GET STH)
Add to word list
Add to word list
a way to get or do something: The laptop is my portal to the outside world. The Post Office has lost any sense that its core business is to provide a portal to delivery services.
internet & telecoms
  specialized a website or page on the internet that allows people, especially a group of people who are interested in a particular subject, to get useful information and to find other websites: A number of large access providers offer portals to the Web for their own users. There are a huge number of knit and crochet resources online, from trade association portals to blogs.

portal noun [C]
(ENTRANCE)
formal (also portals [ plural ]) an entrance to a building, especially a large or important one: Carrell's name remains above the portal to this day. Passing through the portals of the BBC for the first time, she felt slightly nervous.

anatomy , medical
  specialized relating to an opening to an organ in the body, especially the opening where blood vessels (= thin tubes that carry blood) enter the liver (= a large organ that cleans the blood): A liver biopsy reveals portal fibrosis. Nerve fibres are abundant in the liver, particularly in the portal triads.
anatomy , medical
  specialized relating to a system in the body in which blood flows from capillaries (= very thin tubes) of one organ, through larger blood vessels (= tubes), to capillaries of another organ, before returning to the heart : Ultimately these veins drain into the portal system. The problem sometimes results from obstruction of the portal circulation.
anatomy , medical
  specialized relating to the portal vein (= a major vein in the body that leads to the liver): Portal hypertension is a common related condition that is caused by liver damage. Clotting time increases because the high portal pressure backs up blood into the spleen, destroying platelets.
